title: 110_hr2713
content: The Act titled the "Joseph H. Seall Act of 2007" waives the 5-month waiting period for disability benefits for terminally ill beneficiaries. The "Joseph H. Seall Act of 2007" allows the Commissioner of Social Security to waive the waiting period for disability insurance benefits for terminally ill individuals, if it would cause undue hardship. The "Joseph H. Seall Act of 2007" allows the Commissioner of Social Security to waive the waiting period for disability insurance benefits for terminally ill individuals, if it would cause undue hardship. Additionally, the Act also allows for the waiver of the waiting period for widow's insurance benefits based on disability under certain conditions. The Commissioner of Social Security can waive the waiting period for widower's insurance benefits if the individual is terminally ill and it would cause undue hardship. The Commissioner of Social Security may waive the waiting period for disability benefits if the individual is terminally ill and it would cause undue hardship. The Commissioner of Social Security can waive the waiting period for disability benefits if the individual is terminally ill with a life expectancy of 6 months or less. The effective dates for the amendments apply to different sections of the Social Security Act after 90 days from the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. STUDY REGARDING DISABILITY CLAIMS PROCESSING. The Commissioner of Social Security will conduct a study on processing disability insurance claims, including methods used by State agencies and the Social Security Administration, comparing them to other agencies and providers in the private sector. The Commissioner will report recommendations for improving disability determination methods and procedures to address the backlog in processing claims.
